Astronomy Colloquium
Astronomy Colloquium

Friday April 11 - 11:15 AM to 12:15 PM

SWAIN HALL WEST - Room Number: 214

Abstract:  The Star Formation Across Cosmic Time (SFACT) survey utilizes custom narrowband filters to detect objects with strong emission lines.  SFACT sources are found at a range of distances from the local universe out to redshifts of ~5, when the universe was roughly one Gyr old.  Carried out wi...

The Pre-Mongol History of the Khalaj in Eastern Afghanistan
The Pre-Mongol History of the Khalaj in Eastern Afghanistan

Monday April 14 - 04:30 PM to 05:30 PM

Hamilton Lugar School of Global and International Studies - Room Number: 3067

The Khalaj are a people considered to be a branch of Turkish tribes. They live in West Asia, and, if we believe Vladimir Minorsky's hypothesis, some of them have assimilated amongst the Afghans and live there as the Ghilzay. It was also Minorsky who published surviving Turkish dialects of the Khalaj...

Curated by fashion scholar Dr. Heather Akou, Associate Professor at the Eskenazi School of Art, Architecture + Design, "Divine Adornment: Community Stories of Belonging" uses pieces from the museum's collection to explore fashion from an Islamic perspective. Eskenazi School Herman B Wells Professor Arthur Liou's video installation, "Whispers from the Divide", seeks to encapsulate the tangible and intangible barriers between the US-Mexico border. Friday April 25 - 02:00 PM to 03:00 PM

Global and International Studies Building - Room Number: 3067

This talk explores Chornobyl's cinematic legacy from 1972 to 1996, highlighting shifts from Soviet utopian portrayals to post-disaster depictions of trauma, protest, and transnational collaboration. By analyzing underexamined pre- and post-Chornobyl films, it reveals how cinema shaped and reflected ...
